description.content: (2) Warrior from Adresteia, 2.830; killed by Diomedes, 11.328 sqq
(3) Trojan killed by Agamemnon and Menelaos, 6.37 sqq
(1) Youngest son of Priam, killed by Achilleus, 20.407-18
Son of Laomedon, father of Aisepos (2) and Pedasos (1), 6.22
A district, its people allied to the Trojans, in what was later Macedonia, 17.350
Son of Panthoös, killed by Menelaos, 14.516, 17.24
Son of Dardanos, ancestor of the kings of Troy, 20.219
Another, and in the Iliad more usual, name for Paris, q.v
Henchman of Sarpedon, killed by Patroklos, 16.463
Large island south of the Aegean, the domain of Idomeneus, 2.649
City in the domain of Agamemnon, 2.570
Trojan ally from Pedaios, killed by Teukros, 13.170
Augur for the Achaians, 1.68-100, 2.300-332. Impersonated by Poseidon, 13.45
Brother of Hektor, 8.318; killed by Patroklos, 16.737-76
(1) Son of Iphitos (1) and a leader of the Phokians, 2.517; killed by Hektor, 17.304-11
(2) Son of Perimedes, also leader of the Phokians and killed by Hektor, 15.515. (It is quite possible that there is confusion in the tradition here, and that the same man is meant.)
River apparently on the borders of Pylos and Arkadia, 7.135
Son of Priam, killed by Aias, 11.489
(1) A leader of the men from Kos and adjacent islands, 2.678
(3) Son of Priam, killed by Agamemnon, 11.101
Island off the coast of Asia Minor, 2.145
Son of Kronos and Rheia, so younger brother of Zeus, lord of the sea, 15.185-92; protector of the Achaians, 13.10-124, etc
Strait between the Troad and Thrace, now Dardanelles, 2.845, etc
Son of Deukalion, lord of Krete, one of the great princes and fighters of the Achaians, 2.645, etc
Mountain and range in the Troad, 2.821, etc
Son of Hermes and Polymele, a Myrmidon captain, 16.179
(2) Trojan, brother of Maris, killed by Antilochos, 16.317
Of the spear of Achilleus, cut from Mount Pelion, 16.143
City in the domain of Diomedes, 2.560
An Elean hero, father of Diores, 2.622
Augur in Perkote, father of Adrestos (2) and Amphios (1), 2.831
Giant who with his brother Otos imprisoned Ares, 5.385
City in Thessaly, in the domain of Polypoites, 2.739
Mother, by the river Axios, of Pelegon, 21.142
District east of the Troad, allied with Troy, 2.862, etc
Nereïd, given by the gods in marriage to the mortal Peleus, and by him mother of Achilleus, 1.351-457, 18.35-147, etc
Town in the domain of Achilleus, 2.682
(1) Achaian from Arne killed by Paris, 7.9
Father of Zeus, Hades, Poseidon, Hera, Demeter, 1.498, etc.; overthrown and in Tartaros, 8.479-81
Charioteer of Axylos, killed by Diomedes, 6.18
“Son of Atreus,” used of Agamemnon, less often of Menelaos
A spring in the domain of Eurypylos, 2.734
Brother-in-law of Aineias, killed by Idomeneus, 13.427-44
Daughter of Zeus and Dione, mother of Aineias, protectress of Helen, called also the Lady of Kypros, 3.374, etc
The lake by which Boibe was situated, 2.711
A lake, more commonly called Kopais, in Boiotia, 5.709
Husband of Marpessa and father of Kleopatra, who contended against Apollo for the sake of Marpessa, 9.556-60
(1) Son of Herakles and leader of the men from Rhodes, 2.653-70; killed, after severely wounding him, by Sarpedon, 5.628-69
The city of Erechtheus, in east-central Greece, 2.546
Thessalian city in the domain of Philoktetes, 2.717
Also known as Rheia. Mother, by Kronos, of Zeus, Poseidon, Hades, Hera, and Demeter, 15.187-88
Also known as Rhea. Mother, by Kronos, of Zeus, Poseidon, Hades, Hera, and Demeter, 15.187-88
City, location unknown, on the Trojan side, 13.363
Dardanian, son of Panthoös, who struck down Patroklos, 16.806-15; killed by Menelaos, 17.43-60
Companion of Odysseus, killed by Antiphos (3), 4.489-93
Achaian, a great boxer and winner of this event in the games for Patroklos, 23.664-99 (in the Odyssey, 8.493, builder of the Trojan Horse)
An elder of Troy, 3.147; father of Poulydamas, 13.756; of Euphorbos, 16.808; of Hyperenor, 17.19-35
Town near Troy, the home of Chryses, 1.37
Father of Hekabē and of Asios (2), 16.718
Town in the domain of Achilleus, 2.682
Son of Kronos, brother and husband of Hera, most powerful of the gods, 1.5, etc
Island off west-central Greece, in the domain of Odysseus, 2.631
Companion of Aineias, killed by Agamemnon, 5.534
Brother of Eurytos (2), q.v.; father of Amphimachos (1), 2.620-21
City, location unknown, allied to Troy, 2.841
The same as Lakedaimon (q.v.) except that the name Sparta applies only to the city, Lakedaimon to the district as well, 2.582, etc
Properly Aïdes. Son of Kronos and Rhea, full brother of Zeus, Poseidon, Hera, and Demeter, 15.187-92. Lord over the dead, loc. cit.; 1.3, etc. (n.b. A person, not a place.)
Son of Laërtes, lord of Ithaka and the neighboring islands, great fighter and counselor, close friend of Agamemnon, 2.631, etc
Ilion, the city of Tros and of the Trojans, 1.128, etc
A term of disputed and apparently variable significance. Applied to Argos (2), the home of Achilleus, 2.681; but the Pelasgians of Larissa are allied with the Trojans, 2.840-43
Kadmeian who led an ambuscade against Tydeus, 4.393-98
Island just north of Rhodes, its people led by Nireus, 2.671
Priest of Hephaistos in Troy, father of Phegeus and Idaios (2), 5.9
Son of Ares, a chief of Orchomenos, 2.511; killed by Deïphobos, 13.519
Follower of Thymbraios, killed by Odysseus, 11.322
City of the Minyai, near Orchomenos, 2.511
Harpy, mother by the West Wind of the horses of Achilleus, 16.150
A river, and river-god, in Paionia, 2.849
(1) Epeian hero killed by Nestor in his youth, 11.739
People from around the lake of Gyge, 2.864
(1) Trojan ally from Adresteia, son of Merops, 2.830; killed by Diomedes, 11.328
(2) Trojan ally, son of Selagos, killed by Aias, 5.612
The waters surrounding the world and the god of those waters, 1.423, 14.201, etc
Trojan scout, killed by Diomedes and Odysseus, 10.313-464
Leader from Syme, handsomest (next to Achilleus) of the Achaians, 2.671
“Most righteous of the Centaurs,” friend and teacher of Asklepios, 4.219; of Achilleus, 11.832; of Peleus, 16.143
Heroine after whom a hill before Troy was named, 2.814
The messenger of the gods, 2.786, etc
City in Thessaly, in the domain of Polypoites, 2.738
Mother, by Ares, of Askalaphos and Ialmenos, 2.513
(1) City of Eëtion near Troy, sacked by Achilleus, 1.366, etc.
(2) City of the Kadmeians in Boiotia, attacked by Polyneikes and his companions, 4.376-81; and taken by their sons, 4.404-9; only the lower city remaining at the time of the Trojan War, 2.505
City in the domain of Nestor, on the Alpheios, probably identical with the foregoing, 2.592
Daughter of Eëtion, wife of Hektor, 6.371
A leader of the men from Kos and the adjacent islands, 2.678
Builder in Troy, who made ships for Paris, killed by Meriones, 5.59-68
An important counselor of Priam and the Trojans, father of numerous sons who figure in the Iliad, 3.148, 7.347, etc
Smith in Troy, father of Phereklos, 5.60
City in Thessaly, in the domain of Eurypylos, 2.735
(2) Achaian from Mykenai, killed by Hektor, 15.638-52
Thessalian city in the domain of Philoktetes, 2.716
A leader of the Minyai from Orchomenos, 2.512
Son of Antenor, husband of Laodike, 3.123
Son of Antenor, one of the great captains and fighters of Troy. Fights Achilleus, 21.544 sqq
Wife of Menelaos who ran away with Paris, the cause of the war, 3.121, etc
Son of Jason and Hypsipyle, lord in Lemnos, 7.468
Daughter of Idas and Marpessa, wife of Meleagros, 9.556
City in the domain of Agamemnon, 2.571
(1) Daughter of Priam and wife of Helikaon, impersonated by Iris, 3.121-24
(1) Son of Erichthonios, father of Ilos, Assarakos, and Ganymedes, thus ancestor of the kings and princes of Troy, 20.230-40
People of Aitolia in western Greece, led by Thoas, 2.638-44, etc
Achaian from Kythera, friend of Aias, killed by Hektor, 15.429-35
People of Orchomenos (1) led by Askalaphos and Ialmenos, 2.511
Son of Zeus and Leto, chief protector of the Trojans, 1.9, etc
A river in the western Peloponnese, 2.592, etc
City on the borders of Pylos and Arkadia, 7.135
(2) Father of Thestor, 16.402 (perhaps identical with the aforementioned)
Son of Eëtion, friend (possibly brother-in-law) of Hektor, killed by Menelaos, 17.575-81
Thessalian people led by Polypoites and Leonteus, 12.128-30
(2) Father of Thalpios, brother of Kteatos, 2.621; he and his brother called Moliones, 11.709, 11.750
Meaning “descendent of Aiakos,” used of Achilleus
(1) Man of Lesbos, father of Diomede, 9.665
Son of Laomedon, king of Troy, father of Hektor, Paris, and many other children (fifty sons, 24.495), 3.161, etc
Paphlagonian ally of Troy killed by Meriones, 13.643-59
Son of Panthoös, fighter and careful counselor, frequently opposed to the reckless strategy of Hektor, 12.210-29, 18.249-83, etc
(1) Son of Antenor, impersonated by Athene, 4.87
Son of Oineus and father of Diomedes; his genealogy and history, 14.113-25
Mother (by Zeus) of Apollo and Artemis, 1.9, 21.498-504, 24.607-9
River apparently on the borders of Pylos and Arkadia, 7.134
Herald in Troy, father of Dolon, 10.314
Leader of the men from Doulichion, son of Phyleus, 2.627; leader of the Epeians, 13.692
Companion in arms of Idomeneus, one of the most prominent of the younger Achaian warriors, charioteer and archer, 2.651, 13.244-329, etc.
Son of Pelops and brother of Atreus, 2.106
Bastard son of Priam, killed by Odysseus, 4.499
Thessalian city in the domain of Philoktetes, 2.717
A tribe from the Black Sea district, led by Odios (1) and Epistrophos (3), 2.856
Place where Apollo had bred the mares of Eumelos, 2.766
The river (later, at least, a river of the dead, and see 8.369) by which the gods swear, 2.755, etc
Myrmidon, son of Aktor (4), husband of Polymele, 16.189
Son of Assarakos, father of Anchises, so grandfather of Aineias, 20.239
Daughter of Altes, mother, by Priam, of Lykaon (2) and Polydoros (1), 21.84-91
Son of Zeus, called guide and Argeïphontes, 2.104, etc
(1) Son of Euaimon, lord of a district in Thessaly which has not been certainly located, 2.736; wounded and put out of action by Paris, 11.575-95, etc.
Hero of Thebes (1), 23.679. (In Homer, strictly, Oidipodes.)
Son of Tydeus, lord, with Sthenelos and Euryalos, of Argos proper, one of the greatest of the Achaian fighters, prominent in battle until wounded by Paris, 11.368-400
Island off the coast of the Troad, 1.38
Wife of Antenor, 5.70, etc.; priestess of Athene, 6.298-311
Lord of Argos, father of Atreus, 2.104
City of Aitolia, its men led by Thoas, 2.640. For a part of the Kalydonian Saga, see 9.529-99
Son of Priam and Hekabē, who carried Helen from Lakedaimon, 3.15, etc. (in the Iliad more frequently called by his other name, Alexandros)
Uncle of Herakles, killed by Tlepolemos (1) who was his great-nephew, 2.663
Son of Antenor, killed by Achilleus, 20.395
Father of Aias (1) and Teukros, 2.528, 8.283, etc
Of a mountain sacred to Dionysos, 6.133
Of Dardania, or descended from, or pertaining to, Dardanos. Used of the group of Trojans whose lord was Aineias, 2.819
Chief from Askania, 13.793; killed by Meriones, 14.514
City and district of the western Peloponnese, adjoining the domain of Nestor, 2.615, etc
(2) Trojan, son of Agenor, killed by Achilleus, 20.474
(2) River of the Troad, also called Skamandros (q.v.), 6.4, etc.
(5) One of the horses of Achilleus, 16.149, etc
The home of Achilleus, in southern Thessaly, 2.683, etc
Son of Tros (1), caught up among the gods and made immortal, 20.232-35
Achaian of indefinite social and military status, ugly and scurrilous and eloquent, squelched by Odysseus, 2.211-77
Son of Zeus and Hera, fights on the side of the Trojans, 5.30, etc
District in east-central Greece, the domain of Aias the son of Oïleus, 2.527
(1) Son of Hyrtakos, a Trojan ally, killed by Idomeneus, 13.389
(2) Brother of Hekabē and uncle of Hektor, 16.717
Lord of the peoples around Dodona, 2.748
A city at the narrows between Euboia and the mainland, where the ships of the Achaians assembled for the expedition to Troy, 2.303
A lord of Lykia, father of Atymnios and Maris, 16.328
Trojan killed by Odysseus, but only after wounding and nearly killing him, 11.427-55
Island off the shore by Athens, home of Aias (1), 2.557
City or locality in the domain of Odysseus, 2.633
Thessalian city in the domain of Eumelos, 2.712
(1) Bastard son of Oïleus (1), 13.694-97; killed by Aineias, 15.332
(2) A captain on the Trojan side, 17.216
(2) Of Pleuron, a wrestler beaten by Nestor, 23.635
Priest of Apollo, father of Chryseis, 1.11
Son of Antenor, killed by Agamemnon after wounding him, 11.248-63
Wife of Admetos, mother of Eumelos, 2.715
Son of Priam, killed by Diomedes, 5.160
People of Asia Minor who held the city of Miletos, 2.867
Trojan named after the river, killed by Aias, 4.473-89
Giant (later called Typhon) put underground in the land of the Arimoi, 2.783
King of Troy, son of Ilos and father of Priam, Tithonos, Lampos (1), Klytios (1) and Hiketaon, 20.236-38; who earned the hatred of Poseidon by his treatment of him and Apollo, 21.443-60
Charioteer of Poulydamas, killed by Teukros, 15.445-53
Son of Antenor, killed by Aias, 14.463
Bastard son of Telamon, so half brother of Aias (1), archer and spear-fighter, 8.266-334, etc
City near the Spercheios in the domain of Peleus and Achilleus, 2.682
Son of Oidipous, leader of the Seven against Thebes, 4.377
A northern people visited by Ares, 13.301
A race of warrior women who invaded Asia Minor, 3.189, 6.186
(3) One of the leaders of the Myrmidons, 16.193
A leader of the Athenians, killed by Hektor, 15.329-31
Leader of the Magnesians from Pelion, 2.756
Thessalian city in the domain of Eurypylos, 2.734
Landmark on the borders of Elis, 2.617
Thessalian city in the domain of Machaon, 2.729
Daughter of Chryses, captive mistress of Agamemnon, released by him to her father (later Criseyde, Cressida), 1.111, etc.
Son of Priam and Kastianeira, killed by Teukros, 8.302-8
Son of Laomedon, 20.238; father of Melanippos (2), 15.546
Son of Zeus, father of Peleus, 21.189
Son of Zeus and Europa, father of Deukalion, king of Krete, 13.450-54, 14.321-22
Suitor of Kassandra, killed by Idomeneus, 13.363-82
(1) Companion of Sarpedon, second in command of the Lykians, 2.876; wounded by Teukros, 12.387-89
(2) Father of Bellerophontes, great-grandfather of Glaukos (1), 6.154-55
Island just southeast of the Aegean, its men led by Tlepolemos (1), 2.654
Achaian city in the domain of Agamemnon, 2.573
Island and city close to the coast of Asia Minor south of Troy, 9.129, etc
Lord of the Paphlagonians, killed by Menelaos, 5.576-79
Thessalian city of Eurytos (1) in the domain of Podaleirios and Machaon, 2.730
Heroine of Asia, whose six daughters and six sons were killed by Apollo and Artemis, 24.602-17
Charioteer of Hektor, killed by Teukros, 8.312
Olympian goddess of order and custom, 15.87, 20.5
Mountain north of Thessaly, the home of the gods, 1.499, etc
Hero of Kalydon, son of Portheus, 14.117; father of Tydeus, 5.813; of Meleagros, 5.981
Chief river of the Trojan plain, 2.465, etc.; as a god, fights and discomfits Achilleus, 21.211-382; called also, by the gods, Xanthos, 20.74
Thessalian city in the domain of Protesilaos, 2.695
Son of Zeus, father of Polypoites, 2.741
Aged god of the sea, father of Thetis, 1.556; and of the other Nereïds, 18.36
Achaian city in the domain of Agamemnon, 2.573
(1) Father of Euryalos, 2.566 (and one of the Seven against Thebes); a great boxer in his youth, 23.678-80
Son of Antenor, killed by Agamemnon, 11.221-47
City in the Troad, the home of Briseis, 2.690, etc
A northern people visited by Ares, 13.302
Wife of Oïleus (1) and stepmother of Medon (1), 13.697
Son of Zeus and Semele, driven into the sea by Lykourgos, 6.132-37
Leader of the Pylians, once a great warrior and still active as a commander and counselor, 1.247-84, etc.; father of Antilochos, 5.565; of Thrasymedes, 9.81
Island lying close off east-central Greece, 2.536
City in Thessaly, in the domain of Protesilaos, 2.697
The great healer, father of Machaon and Podaleirios, 2.731
Or Lekton, promontory of the Troad, 14.284
Of one of the gates of Troy, 3.145, etc
A dream-interpreter, father of Abas and Polyidos (1), 5.149
Hero of the generation of Nestor, 1.264
A leader of the Boiotians, 2.495; killed by Agenor, 15.340
(1) Son of Laomedon, father of Dolops (2), 15.525-27
Daughter of Peleus, mother, by the river Spercheios, of Menesthios, 16.173-78
Son of Anchises and Aphrodite, leader of the Dardanians, 2.820, etc
Trojan, son of Antenor, killed by Meges, 5.69-75
Island in the domain of Meges, 2.625
(1) Son of Kapaneus, leader, with Diomedes and Euryalos, of the men of Argos (1), 2.563-64; companion in arms and charioteer of Diomedes, 5.108, etc.
Thessalian city in the domain of Polypoites, 2.738
Follower and charioteer of Achilleus and Patroklos, a considerable warrior in his own right, 16.145, 17.429
Hero from Korinth, killer of the Chimaira, grandfather of Sarpedon and Glaukos (now usually called Bellerophon), 6.155-202.
Son of Hera, 1.571; artificer, 1.607, etc.; fire god, 21.330-81, etc
The city, with its surrounding country, of Menelaos, in southeastern Greece, 2.581, etc
Named as his father by Hermes to Priam, 24.398
Place in Epeiros in extreme northwest Greece, site of an oracle of Zeus, 2.750, 16.233
Islands in the domain of Meges, 2.625
Leatherworker of Hyle, who made the great shield of Aias, 7.220-24
Leader of the men from Phylake, etc., first of the Achaians to land at Troy and first to be killed, 2.695-709
Leader of the Kikones impersonated by Apollo, 17.73
People from the region of Dodona, led by Gouneus, 2.749
Son of Peleus and Thetis, (Peleion, Peleides) leader of the Myrmidons, 1.7, etc
(1) Hero of Krete, father of Idomeneus, 12.117, 13.451
Trojan ally from Perkote, killed by Odysseus, 6.30
(2) Herald for Odysseus, 2.184. (The two are probably the same person.)
The daughters of Nereus, nymphs of the sea, 18.36-49
The people of Boiotia, in central Greece northwest of Attica, 2.494
Leader, with Leïtos, of the Boiotians, 2.494
The domain, or part of the domain, of Peleus, 2.683, etc
Son of Atreus (therefore sometimes called Atreides), brother of Menelaos, king of Mykenai and chief leader of the Achaians, 1.24, etc
Town in Pylos by the Alpheios, 11.711
(1) Place-name denoting sometimes a city (under the sway of Diomedes), sometimes a larger district in the northeast Peloponnese, and used also to mean simply “Greece.”
(2) Pelasgian Argos, the domain of Achilleus
River on the border of Nestor’s domain, 11.722
Hero of the generation of Nestor, 1.264
People of Paphlagonia on the southern shore of the Black Sea, allied to the Trojans, 2.851
(1) Hero buried in the Trojan plain, 2.793
God of the sea, father of Briareos, 1.404
Thessalian city in the domain of Polypoites, 2.739
Island in the domain of Argos, 2.562
Leader of the Karians, killed by Achilleus, 2.867-75
(1) Son of Antenor and companion of Aineias, killed by Meriones, 16.342
City once ruled by Adrestos (1) in the domain of Agamemnon, 2.572
King of Cyprus who gave a corselet to Agamemnon, 11.20
(2) Son of Priam, augur and fighter, 6.76, 6.576, etc
King of the Leleges, whose daughter, Laothoë, was one of Priam’s wives, 21.85.
(1) King of the Thracians, killed by Diomedes, 10.432-502
Son of Priam, field commander of the Trojans and their greatest fighter, killer of Patroklos, 16.816- 42; killed by Achilleus, 22.273-363
(1) Son of Telamon, “Telamonian” Aias, of Salamis, 2.557, etc
(2) Son of Oïleus, of Lokris, 2.527-30, etc
District to the northwest of the Aegean, later part of Macedonia, 14.226
Son of Laomedon and brother of Priam, 20.237; husband of the Dawn, 11.1
City in the domain of Philoktetes, 2.716
City in the domain of Diomedes, 2.562
Trojan ally, leader of the Kikonians, 2.846
(1) Trojan huntsman and fighting man killed by Menelaos, 5.49-58
That small infantry warred on by cranes, 3.6
Daughter of Dymas, Priam’s queen, 6.251, 22.79, etc
Island off the western coast of Greece, part of the domain of Odysseus, 2.634
Daughter of Phoinix, mother of Minos and Rhadamanthys, 14.321
Leader, with Peneleos, of the Boiotians, 2.494; wounded and put out of action by Hektor, 17.601-4
River by Troy, tributary of Skamandros, 5.774, etc
(1) Son of Andraimon, leader of the Aitolians, 2.638; one of the more important younger chiefs, characterized, 15.281-84
Priest of Skamandros in Troy, father of Hypsenor (1), 5.77
Son of Zeus and Europa, brother of Minos, 14.321-22
Son of Aktor (3) and father of Patroklos, 1.307, etc
(4) One of the horses of Achilleus, 16.152
Thessalian city in the domain of Eumelos, 2.712
Creatures, part human and part beast, at home around Mount Pelion, 11.832
Daughter of Priam, wife of Imbrios, 13.173
City on the European side of the Hellespont, its people allies of Troy, 2.836
A wine used medicinally, origin unknown, 11.639
Achaian with a big voice, impersonated by Hera, 5.785
Son of Portheus, brother of Oineus, 14.117
Son of Eurytos (2), leader of the Epeians, 2.620
(1) Son of Zeus, father of Erichthonios, ancestor of the Trojan kings, 20.215
(2) Son of Bias, killed by Achilleus, 20.460
Son of Atreus, brother of Agamemnon, first husband of Helen, lord of Lakedaimon, 2.581-90, etc
Trojan ally from Arisbe, killed by Diomedes, 6.12
Island on the homeward route of Paris from Lakedaimon, 3.445
Son of Oineus and prince of Kalydon, 9.529-99
A people at war with the Aitolians, 9.529-99
Son of Peirithoös, leader of the Lapithai from Argissa, etc., 2.740, etc
In Homer, only of the people in Asian Thebe, 6.397, 6.415
Daughter of Bellerophontes, mother, by Zeus, of Sarpedon, 6.197-99
Thessalian city in the domain of Podaleirios and Machaon, 2.729
Leader, with Polypoites, of the Lapithai from Argissa, etc., 2.745
(1) One of the horses of Hektor, 8.185
(2) One of the horses of Menelaos, 23.295
River of Asia Minor emptying near Miletos (2), 2.869
Thessalian city in the domain of Polypoites, 2.739
The seaboard and inlying territory north of the Aegean, the inhabitants called Thracians, 9.5, 10.434, etc
City on the Argive coast in the domain of Diomedes, 2.561
The two called Aias when spoken of together
Island off west-central Greece, the home of Odysseus, 2.632, etc
City in the domain of Diomedes, 2.561
One of the immortal horses of Achilleus, 16.149
Tribe in Asia Minor; Bellerophontes fought against them, 6.184-85
King of Ephyra, who designed against the life of Bellerophontes, 6.156-70
Thracian singer ruined by the Muses, 2.594-600
(1) City in the domain of Nestor, 2.594
(2) City in the domain of Protesilaos, 2.697
